document_metadata.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(−)-Nicotine: “A Drug for All Seasons

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, immediately after exposure to nicotine, there is a “stimulant-kick” caused, in part, by its stimulation of the adrenal glands and resultant discharge of epinephrine (adrenaline)

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, immediately after exposure to nicotine, there is a “stimulant-kick” caused, in part, by its stimulation of the adrenal glands and resultant discharge of epinephrine (adrenaline)

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Nicotine also suppresses insulin output from the pancreas, which indicates that smokers are usually hyperglycemic (higher blood sugar level)

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Centrally, (-)-nicotine has affinity for all brain nAChR subtypes, but binds preferentially and with high affinity to α4β2 nAChRs (e.g., [12, 13])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Centrally, (-)-nicotine has affinity for all brain nAChR subtypes, but binds preferentially and with high affinity to α4β2 nAChRs (e.g., [12, 13])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: (-)-Nicotine activates all brain nAChR subtypes, but binds preferentially and with high affinity to α4β2 nAChRs (e.g., [12])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Moreover, (-)-nicotine (indirectly) can produce a release of dopamine in brain regions that are thought to control pleasure and motivation; dopamine is thought to underlie the pleasurable sensations experienced by smokers (e.g., [14, 15] but see [16]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, (-)-nicotine may increase dopamine activity at some brain sites such as the nucleus accumbens, an area thought to be important to drugs of abuse (e.g., [14, 101, 102]; but see [16, 103])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, in rodents, administration of low doses of nicotine produced increased motor activity whereas high doses produced decreased motor activity (e.g.,[17, 18])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: . It is now well established that nicotine binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) at the cellular level and is the prototype drug used to classify nAChRs

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: (-)-Nicotine activates all brain nAChR subtypes, but binds preferentially and with high affinity to α4β2 nAChRs (e.g., [12])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In antagonism tests, (-)-nicotine failed to block the stimulus effects of mecamylamine

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: . It should be noted that hexamethonium, at relatively low doses, does not block the stimulus effects of (-)-nicotine but when administered at high doses has occasionally been reported to attenuate nicotine-like responding; probably the result of penetration into the CNS of a small proportion of the administered dose of drug (e.g., [35, 38, 64, 106, 146])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: The release of epinephrine stimulates the body and causes a sudden release of glucose as well as an increase in blood pressure, respiration, and heart rate

links.evidence: The release of epinephrine stimulates the body and causes a sudden release of glucose as well as an increase in blood pressure, respiration, and heart rate

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In comparison, S(-)-nicotine was shown to be 7 times more toxic than R(+)-nicotine in rats injected intravenously

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Lastly, S(-)-nornicotine is a minor metabolite of nicotine and, as mentioned previously, is considered a minor alkaloid of tobacco (Fig. 2)

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In the body, nicotine is extensively metabolized and is susceptible to a significant first-pass effect during which 80–90% of it is metabolized by the liver. Also, the lung is able to metabolize nicotine, but to a much lesser degree [78, 79].

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In humans, about 70–80% of nicotine is converted to the primary metabolite (-)-cotinine, a lactam derivative (Fig. 2).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Lastly, S(-)-nornicotine is a minor metabolite of nicotine and, as mentioned previously, is considered a minor alkaloid of tobacco (Fig. 2)

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In the body, nicotine is extensively metabolized and is susceptible to a significant first-pass effect during which 80–90% of it is metabolized by the liver. Also, the lung is able to metabolize nicotine, but to a much lesser degree [78, 79].

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, some biochemical studies suggest that mecamylamine is a channel blocker that inhibits most neuronal nAChRs (e.g., [131–133]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Mecamylamine (Inversine®, Vecamyl®; Fig. 3) was developed over 60 years ago and marketed as a ganglionic blocker for the treatment of hypertension (e.g., [127])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: In addition, mecamylamine can produce CNS effects that include tremor, mental confusion, seizures, mania, and depression but the mechanisms by which these effects are produced are unclear

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Biochemical and pharmacological studies have characterized mecamylamine as a nonselective, voltage dependent and noncompetitive receptor antagonist of neuronal nAChRs and it is often referred to as a “nicotine receptor antagonist.”

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Research results summarized in Table 5 indicate that DHβE effectively blocked the stimulus effects of (-)-nicotine in rats or mice (but see exceptions reported by [120, 121]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: DHβE (Fig. 3) is an alkaloid found in plant seeds of Erythrina and is a competitive nAChR receptor antagonist with a preference for neuronal β2 subtypes

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: DHβE (Fig. 3) is an alkaloid found in plant seeds of Erythrina and is a competitive nAChR receptor antagonist with a preference for neuronal β2 subtypes

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, DHβE (at nM concentrations) blocks α4β2 and α3β2 nAChRs but is much less potent at α3β4 and α7 nAChRs expressed in Xenopus oocytes (e.g., [134–137]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: For example, DHβE (at nM concentrations) blocks α4β2 and α3β2 nAChRs but is much less potent at α3β4 and α7 nAChRs expressed in Xenopus oocytes (e.g., [134–137]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Table 5 presents results of MLA/(-)-nicotine combination studies and shows that MLA failed to alter the stimulus effects of (-)-nicotine in rats or mice (but see partial antagonism reported by Quarta et al. [126])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: This conclusion is based on the fact that the stimulus effects of nicotine are convincingly blocked by (a) mecamylamine, a voltage dependent noncompetitive channel blocker at nicotinic receptors (Fig. 3; Table 4) and (b) dihydro-β-erythrodine (DHβE), a nicotinic receptor antagonist that shows high affinity for the nAChR α4β2 subunit (Fig. 3; Table 5) but not by methyllycaconitine (MLA), a α7 nicotinic receptor antagonist (Table 5).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Its biochemical pharmacology indicates that it is a relatively potent competitive receptor antagonist that is selective for α7 nAChRs (e.g., [139–141]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Also, mecamylamine is sometimes used as an anti-addictive drug to help people stop smoking tobacco products (e.g.,[128, 129])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Also, mecamylamine is sometimes used as an anti-addictive drug to help people stop smoking tobacco products (e.g.,[128, 129])

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: (-)-Nicotine withdrawal symptoms might begin within a few hours after the last nicotine product, and include irritability/anger/stress/anxiety, sleep disturbances, depressed mood, craving, cognitive and attention deficits, and increased appetite.

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: It is prescribed as medication for the treatment of depression (Wellbutrin®) and/or as an adjunct in smoking cessation therapy (Zyban®).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Varenicline (Chantix®; Fig. 4) is prescribed as an adjunct medication in smoking cessation therapy and is thought to exert its effects as a partial agonist at α4β2 nAChRs and as a full agonist at α7 nAChRs [211, 212].

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Lobeline binds with high affinity to α4β2 nAChRs and displays mixed receptor agonist/antagonist actions (e.g., [150–154]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Lobeline has, however, been shown to antagonize partially the stimulus effects of (-)-nicotine and S(+)-methamphetamine ([64, 160]; but see [66]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Lobeline has, however, been shown to antagonize partially the stimulus effects of (-)-nicotine and S(+)-methamphetamine ([64, 160]; but see [66]).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Bupropion [a.k.a. amfebutamone, (RS)-2-(tert-Butylamino)-1-(3-chlorophenyl)propan1-one, 3-Chloro tert-butylcathinone, 3-Chloro-N-tert-butyl-β-ketoamphetamine; Fig. 4] is a phenylaminoketone or cathinone derivative that is a weak central nervous system (CNS) stimulant

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: It is prescribed as medication for the treatment of depression (Wellbutrin®) and/or as an adjunct in smoking cessation therapy (Zyban®).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: It is prescribed as medication for the treatment of depression (Wellbutrin®) and/or as an adjunct in smoking cessation therapy (Zyban®).

citation.name: Discriminative Stimulus Properties of S(-)-Nicotine: "A Drug for All Seasons".

links.evidence: Other studies have reported that bupropion blocked the acute effects of (-)-nicotine in a number of behavioral assays in mice (e.g., [171, 172])
